description: From Middle English table, tabel, tabil, tabul, from Old English tabele, tabul, tablu, tabule, tabula (“board”); also as tæfl, tæfel, an early Germanic borrowing of Latin tabula (“tablet, board, plank, chart”). The sense of “piece of furniture” is from Old French table, of same Latin origin; Old English used bēod or bord instead for this meaning: see board. Doublet of tabula.

definitionGroups.group: Furniture with a top surface to accommodate a variety of uses.

entries.meaning: An item of furniture with a flat top surface raised above the ground, usually on one or more legs.
The board or table-like furniture on which a game is played, such as snooker, billiards, or draughts.
A flat tray which can be used as a table.
A supply of food or entertainment.
examples: The baron kept a fine table and often held large banquets.

entries.meaning: A service of Holy Communion.
(backgammon) One half of a backgammon board, which is divided into the inner and outer table.

definitionGroups.group: A group of people at a table, for example for a meal or game.

entries.meaning: (poker, metonymically) The lineup of players at a given table.
examples: That's the strongest table I've ever seen at a European Poker Tour event

entries.meaning: (role-playing games) A group of players meeting regularly to play a campaign.
A matrix or grid of data arranged in rows and columns.
A collection of arithmetic calculations arranged in a table, such as multiplications in a multiplication table.
examples: The children were practising multiplication tables.
Here is a table of natural logarithms.

entries.meaning: (computing, chiefly databases) A lookup table, most often a set of vectors.
(sports) A visual representation of a classification of teams or individuals based on their success over a predetermined period.
(music) The top of a stringed instrument, particularly a member of the violin family: the side of the instrument against which the strings vibrate.
The flat topmost facet of a cut diamond.

verbs.description: table (third-person singular simple present tables, present participle tabling, simple past and past participle tabled)

entries.meaning: To tabulate; to put into a table or grid. [from 15th c.]
(now rare) To supply (a guest, client etc.) with food at a table; to feed. [from 15th c.]
examples: At Siena I was tabled in the house of one Alberto Scipioni

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To delineate; to represent, as in a picture; to depict. [17th–19th c.]
examples: tabled and pictured in the chambers of meditation

entries.meaning: (non-US) To put on the table of a commission or legislative assembly; to propose for formal discussion or consideration, to put on the agenda. [from 17th c.]
examples: In a raucous Commons, the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, confirmed he had tabled a formal motion of confidence in the government, backed by other opposition leaders, which MPs would vote on on Wednesday.

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) To remove from the agenda, to postpone dealing with; to shelve (to indefinitely postpone consideration or discussion of something). [from 19th c.]
examples: The legislature tabled the amendment, so they will not be discussing it until later.
The motion was tabled, ensuring that it would not be taken up until a later date.

entries.meaning: (carpentry, obsolete) To join (pieces of timber) together using coaks. [18th–19th c.]
To put on a table. [from 19th c.]
examples: [A]fter some clatter offered us a rent of five pounds for the right to shoot here, and even tabled the cash that moment, and would not pocket it again.

entries.meaning: (nautical) To make board hems in the skirts and bottoms of (sails) in order to strengthen them in the part attached to the bolt-rope.
